hints_html:
Representing a complex number in the plane; can you geometrically describe what are the values \(r\) and \(\theta\)?

To follow on the previous hint:

  • \(r\) is the modulus (or absolute value) of a complex number and represents its distance to the origin.

  • \(\theta\) is the argument of a complex number and represents the angle between the line joining the point to the origin and the positive real axis.

See the Wikipedia entry for absolute value and argument of a complex number.

hints_raw:
Representing a complex number in the plane; can you geometrically describe what are the values <math>r</math> and <math>\theta</math>?
To follow on the previous hint:
* <math>r</math> is the modulus (or absolute value) of a complex number and represents its distance to the origin.
* <math>\theta</math> is the argument of a complex number and represents the angle between the line joining the point to the origin and the positive real axis.

See [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_number#Absolute_value_and_argument the Wikipedia entry for absolute value and argument of a complex number].
question: A 20
sols_html:
The absolute value (or modulus) of a complex number \(a+bi\) is

\[\begin{aligned} r = \sqrt{a^2+b^2}=\sqrt{(-1)^2+1^2}=\sqrt 2\end{aligned}\]

and the argument, \(\theta\), is the angle between the right side of the \(x\)-axis and the position of the complex number on the plane. In this case, the argument is \(3\pi /4\). To see that, you can either just visually see that the point (-1,1) is clearly on the diagonal of the second quadrant of the plane, or using trigonometry have

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(\theta)=\frac{a}{r}=\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} \quad\text{and}\quad \sin(\theta)=\frac{b}{r}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and from there notice that the corresponding angle is \(3\pi /4\) (or in real life compute the angle using a calculator since you only know a very few values of sine and cosine).

So this allows us to write our complex number in polar form as

\[\begin{aligned} -1+i=re^{\theta i}=\sqrt 2 e^{3\pi i/4}\end{aligned}\]
